content:
er 24, 2013
												StarConflict was honest and skill-dependent 3d space arcade.With quite nice graphical part and high potential. New friends have been found, and some of best time spent playing.Due to greedy managing and questionable developers all positive sides degraded into awful matter.This is not simply a Pay2Win game. This is a Keep Paying 2 Win. (©Gizmo.mac)Greed is good. This is developer’s motto. Development process was simplified: Create new IMBA ship which will dominate the battlefield.Make it expensive and available for real money. Make grind to new ship long and painful.As soon as ordinary players get enough resources to get this dominating ship - nerf it, and roll out new IMBA.Even investing 600$ may only grant you domination for a month or two, then your precious ship will be nerfed to brick.You pay more, or die from another "happy customer" as everyone else.Nobody cares about player’s opinion. Player can be banned for little to no reason. But - if you invest enough money in game - your ban can be revoked, allowing you to scam, grief and cheat again.Forum ban can be gained just for having your own opinion, or not hailing developers.In-game chat ban can be gained just automatically - with no reason.Full account ban can be gained by cheating, or arguing with GM, or writing a negative Steam review.All bans can be revoked by writing a positive Steam review.Look at game time on positive reviews - how much players recently exceed game time of 100 hours? Targem just forges positive ratings by face accounts IMO.There is no control over GM's and CM's, with complete disrespect to players from their side.Example - Community manger calling me "scum" constantly on his stream, ended up treating to ban my whole team - because he was killed and we were clearly winning.Another example - league system discussion stream. Top corporation’s leaders present, decision was made that leagues will be in 8vs8 format.Leagues were started as 4vs4 - nobody cares about player’s opinion, even if they ask.For all years of the game existence I witnessed an ad less than five times.When the game was released on Steam - there were high online - for a month. Somehow people in charge wasn't aware that their servers already operated at peak power, and lots of new players just pushed the system to lag hell.No new servers were added, new players went elsewhere, and with maximum online of 600 I may get "Server under heavy load" message.Now, what will you get if you will try to play StarConflict now?Until you will reach Rank 4 ships - there will be a pale shadow of its former beauty and glory.Almost balanced, somewhat slow, with less options for modules but so nice.Progressing further will bring you into feeding frenzy of epic proportions. Unless you will invest A LOT in the game - you will be cannon fodder. Again and again, with progression slowed on purpose, hard caps on income unless by money investment and matchmaking weird enough to put you against ships 5 ranks higher than yours.Old days, when skill determined an outcome of the fight are gone. It's hard to overcome auto-aiming weapons, auto-healing enemy ships, and your team hiding under brown rocks whole match.Certain team compositions are unkillable on progression ships. Until you will farm or pay enough to get a counter-class ship yourself - you will be farmed. With little to no chance you will be stomped upon.If your stats become high - expect totally useless team as a boulder on your neck, have a happy time carrying these. And again. And again.And be prepared - some in-game activity can be accessed only through third-party site. There are no control about that site, but rewards and progression are counted on it. So pay no attention if there are shifts in final teams, or people not present in battles are rewarded.Latest addition - game items stockpile are limited now - so you can't stockpile resources now, you have no motivation to do quests, or everything you gain get burned.All my DLC are next to useless now.All my premium ships are next to useless now.All my time spent on leveling progression ships is wasted now.This is official cheating from developers.Conclusion: Targem and Gaijin combined efforts have killed StarConflict. Not worthy of your time now, not recommended anymore. R.I.P.Yes this Review is copy paste one to one from  my friend and wingmate Devouder. And he beat with then the nail on thead.I loved the game, spend a lot of hours in there and now.. i see them fall.

content:
y 3, 2015
												I'll start by saying I love this game. I set it aside from time to time but always end up coming back. The graphics engine is beautiful, if you like sci fi ships this game has them in droves. A vast array of technological marvels to fly around and blow stuff up with.  The flight and shooting mechanics I find to be very tight and responsive. Sound effects are spot on, very satisfying and visceral.The downside is the progression system is extremely grindy if you don't spend real money. Its not so bad if you are enjoying the gameplay, but sadly despite having several pvp and even pve modes, one can get burnt out because the gameplay itself doesn't vary much. Aim your reticle at enemies, fire until they explode, rinse and repeat. There are plenty of modules to give different abilities to your ship, hull and shield repairs, additional weapons or drones, disables, and while they do add variety I find myself wishing for a broader spectrum of tools to use to liven up the gameplay after a while.I do still greatly enjoy it. Nothing around that I'm aware of that scratches the same spacey dogfighting itch while also being accessible, populated, and beautiful. But do be aware that while the game does not have a hard pay wall, it does make progress difficult past tier 2 without at least a small investment. I've spent money on this game, more than I'd like to admit. But I do it because the core game is fantastic, space battle goodness that deserves to be paid for.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
6, 2014
												I used to really, really love this game. It was practically the definition of a good space-dogfighting game, blending the simple fun of an arcade title with the variety of a futuristic space-combat "simulator" in a way that captured the best elements of both. Unfortunately, development has taken a turn for the worse and I've recently joined the roughly 40% of the registered playerbase that's quit within the past year.This game has become a classic example of a great idea with a poor execution. Players new to this title can expect some fun gameplay at first, marred by some big problems. More time is spent queueing for matches than actually in them. It takes forever to unlock new levels and upgrades. The game is almost entirely server-side and Russian-based, so EU and US players can expect input lag. The monetization scheme is overpriced and somewhat pay-to-win. The developers will try to deny or cover up the existence of bugs rather than fix them. There is no actual anti-cheat software of any sort (although admittedly the game's server-side nature somewhat limits cheating). The developers have a very limited and somewhat antagonistic relationship with the community. The game's glaring problems are common, known to the playerbase, and rarely fixed.A year ago I still recommended this game, but now this free title isn't even worth the download time. Check out the variety of other space-combat games Steam has to offer; give this one a pass.

r 4, 2014
												I personally think this game is awesome, I like flying spaceships, mainly the guards but dont mind playing the engineer from time to time.Advantages of Star Conflict:There are different types of roles you can play, such as Fighter, tackler, frigate-(Guard, Long Range and Engineer) and interceptor.You can respawn as many times as you want.Loads of different maps-(Inclueding SOME massive ones)The amount of detail on ships, background's etc. are awesomeDifferent types of weapons/ModulesDifferent types of modes-(Beacon Hunt, combat Reacon ETC.)Disadvantages of StarConflict:I really find annoying the amount of time you have to wait, to get into a battle. E.G: 3-5mins to get in one battle-(Somtimes less).Grinding takes a long time-(but in a way it is good cause you cant rush through the game like in a day or so)The battle's dont last that long. Cant remember the correct time of the battles but no more than 10minutes, cause when you are flying a frigate and they are slow, and you get a massive map, it will take you ages to get from the spawn point to the area you want to get to.Factions are to upgrade your weapons/modules from MK-3 to MK-4 but it used to be free when you changed contracts but now they changed it where you now have to pay credits-(In game money) or gold. Changing contracts means changing hangers but different weapons/modules use different contracts. BUT one good thing is that you keep the loyalty vouchers when changing. Cost to change faction from 200.000 to 750.000.Overall this game is GREAT and I will recommend StarConflict to people who love flying spaceships.I will give StarConflict 8/10. I am giving them this score because they changed the factions. If they did not mess around with that I would of gave them 10/10

number of helpful: 5 of 9 people (56%) found this review helpful
content:
6, 2015
												There are a lot of people who dislike this game. Before you believe what they say, go and look at how long they have played.  If it is less than 100 hours, I guarantee they are still learning how this game works. I have TONS of time invested in this game, and I can honestly say this is the best game I have ever played.  Why?  Well, it's free for starters, and that's a huge plus.Many free games favor premium players—the ones who actually pay for in-game content—so that the incentive becomes to pay for content to gain the upper-hand.  While there is premium content in this game, it is not at all overpowered.  In fact, there are many veteran players like myself who choose regular ships over premium ships because we know the real difference between them and can make the right decision.  The truth is, while there are plenty of people who Pay to Win in this game, they do not win because of their money.  They win because of their time spent learning this complex game and growing from each battle—every win, every defeat.  There is plenty wrong with this game, however, but I see it more as a challenge than a hinderance.  First, the developers are Russian, so it is difficult to be in contact with them.  This might seem minor, but it has grown to become one of the biggest issues in the community.  However, much of the community is active on the forums, so we do have some contact, but mostly with moderators and game masters.  Secondly, the game is hardly advertised.  Obviously, this is a problem.  But the BIGGEST problem in the game is the lack of players, which kind of comes from the aforementioned issues.  I do not believe this issue will last, however; many are coming to the game because it is exciting, and it is growing...albeit slowly.I really do love this game; it's a wondrous space-fighter with plenty of action and ships to choose from.  The grind in this game is very long, but it's worth it.  To be honest, it has to be this long because of how complex it is.  Too many people simply buy their way into T5 (the highest rank) and end up really bad.  Why?  Because they did not play their way to the top like most others.  This might be the longest way, and it might well be the most annoying way, but it is by far the best way to become good at this game.So, if you are on the fence about whether or not to try this game, please, trust me—it is definitely worth a try.  What have you got to lose besides time?  It's well worth the time if you enjoy blowing things up, that's for sure.  Also, if you love space fighters, this is a game to check out and keep at it.Do not give up in the beginning.  It is hard.  It is REALLY hard, especially when all the ships in T1 (the lowest rank) are all terrible.  When you get into T3 (basically the mid-game), you will see the game's beauty.  The epic fights, the ferocious clashes, the immense strategy.Play this game, you will not regret it unless you give up.

number of helpful: 5 of 9 people (56%) found this review helpful
content:
er 17, 2013
												Star Conflict is a 3D PvP arcade space shooter made by Russian devs, with plenty of progression to go through, and a typically smooth difiiculty curve. It's been an excellent time sink for me, with a great concept with wonderful graphics (that still runs pretty nicely - with the exception of one map - on integrated graphics if turned down a tad) and a neat community that has its own quirks. As it's free, if anyone asked me whether or not to give it a go, I'd say absolutely. That's not that it doesn't have its problems, though.Perhaps the worst of these is the blatant monetization. It was less apparent when I started, probably a combination both of more monetization as you progress and more monetization as time went on, but at this point, it's practically screaming for money. There's myriad kinds of in game currency, eight of which are free, and one of which is premium. The primary currency, credits, is earned by simply playing - neat enough. But six of the remaining require you to do certain tasks while playing, many of which are extremely difficult. Even if you do complete some, these tasks are then put on cooldown for some value of time between nothing - for the lowest paying ones - or 17 hours - for the highest. Complicating matters further, one can only earn two of these six at a time, and must pay roughly 20 minutes worth of credits to change which two - or skimp out and pay with premium. These six currencies are used to pay for certain equipment upgrades, which can also be skimped out on and paid with premium. The other free currency not yet talked about is perhaps the only one in abundance that doesn't really encourage anyone to skip out and pay with premium for. The premium problem does go a bit further, yes, but not that much. There exist premium ships in the game, and while they typically have a slight advantage - easier progression, no upkeep fees, the tiniest of extra customization, get in the same queue as a slightly lower ranked free ship - they're not honestly that great. I've used one myself, and heard from several veteran players that they're not that much better, and in some cases, are even slightly worse than their free counterparts. Premium currency can be used for the things mentioned in the paragraph above, but those are mostly convenience fees, albeit "convenience" in the sense of "how it should have been done in the first place because the system is a tad bit too grindy for most people". But perhaps the biggest travesty is that customization of ships - and I'm not talking about buying passive modules and such - is so ridiculous. To buy a colour, one must pay roughly a dollar's worth of real world money. Each ship has three colours, even, so to fully customize a ship, that's three dollars. Now, that might not sound ridiculous, but these colours do not transfer to any other ship, and if you wish to change the colour once and then back again, you'll have to pay to change it twice. Same deal for stickers. You can't simply "unlock" a colour or a sticker, neither for your fleet nor for you ship, but must instead buy them on a per-instance basis. Now, all that said, would I still recommend this game? Hell yes. Even if monetization is being pushed ridiculously hard, it's still a /good game/ at its core. There's no other game out there that makes use of the third dimension like this one. The mechanics are still wonderful as ever. My favourite part is that skill is valued over hardware, 90% of the time. There's both a casual base and a competitive base, so there's neither a push nor a restraint on getting better at the game. There's an official forum where the active community gets together and talks about the game, as well as whatever else. And asking for help gets you help, almost always. tl;dr : The game is great on graphics, sound, mechanics, community, and originality. It's got huge problems on the monetization front, as well as some others not mentioned in the review (lack of tutorials, bad playerbase/dev communication, lag, newbie hunters, and community drama), but it's still a great game.

number of helpful: 5 of 9 people (56%) found this review helpful
content:
er 17, 2013
												Star Conflict is a 3D PvP arcade space shooter made by Russian devs, with plenty of progression to go through, and a typically smooth difiiculty curve. It's been an excellent time sink for me, with a great concept with wonderful graphics (that still runs pretty nicely - with the exception of one map - on integrated graphics if turned down a tad) and a neat community that has its own quirks. As it's free, if anyone asked me whether or not to give it a go, I'd say absolutely. That's not that it doesn't have its problems, though.Perhaps the worst of these is the blatant monetization. It was less apparent when I started, probably a combination both of more monetization as you progress and more monetization as time went on, but at this point, it's practically screaming for money. There's myriad kinds of in game currency, eight of which are free, and one of which is premium. The primary currency, credits, is earned by simply playing - neat enough. But six of the remaining require you to do certain tasks while playing, many of which are extremely difficult. Even if you do complete some, these tasks are then put on cooldown for some value of time between nothing - for the lowest paying ones - or 17 hours - for the highest. Complicating matters further, one can only earn two of these six at a time, and must pay roughly 20 minutes worth of credits to change which two - or skimp out and pay with premium. These six currencies are used to pay for certain equipment upgrades, which can also be skimped out on and paid with premium. The other free currency not yet talked about is perhaps the only one in abundance that doesn't really encourage anyone to skip out and pay with premium for. The premium problem does go a bit further, yes, but not that much. There exist premium ships in the game, and while they typically have a slight advantage - easier progression, no upkeep fees, the tiniest of extra customization, get in the same queue as a slightly lower ranked free ship - they're not honestly that great. I've used one myself, and heard from several veteran players that they're not that much better, and in some cases, are even slightly worse than their free counterparts. Premium currency can be used for the things mentioned in the paragraph above, but those are mostly convenience fees, albeit "convenience" in the sense of "how it should have been done in the first place because the system is a tad bit too grindy for most people". But perhaps the biggest travesty is that customization of ships - and I'm not talking about buying passive modules and such - is so ridiculous. To buy a colour, one must pay roughly a dollar's worth of real world money. Each ship has three colours, even, so to fully customize a ship, that's three dollars. Now, that might not sound ridiculous, but these colours do not transfer to any other ship, and if you wish to change the colour once and then back again, you'll have to pay to change it twice. Same deal for stickers. You can't simply "unlock" a colour or a sticker, neither for your fleet nor for you ship, but must instead buy them on a per-instance basis. Now, all that said, would I still recommend this game? Hell yes. Even if monetization is being pushed ridiculously hard, it's still a /good game/ at its core. There's no other game out there that makes use of the third dimension like this one. The mechanics are still wonderful as ever. My favourite part is that skill is valued over hardware, 90% of the time. There's both a casual base and a competitive base, so there's neither a push nor a restraint on getting better at the game. There's an official forum where the active community gets together and talks about the game, as well as whatever else. And asking for help gets you help, almost always. tl;dr : The game is great on graphics, sound, mechanics, community, and originality. It's got huge problems on the monetization front, as well as some others not mentioned in the review (lack of tutorials, bad playerbase/dev communication, lag, newbie hunters, and community drama), but it's still a great game.

												used to play this game for a long while, until I got bored of this game. The space combat is cool and all but building ships takes a long to do, unless you pay for the bundle packs in the game in which your chances of getting the item or rare part you trying to get will random and pay again and again... you can go mining in open space but that will take too long, sense it's random what you find from astroids and ships that got destroyed and drop random stuff too. Tho you can do matches with some random players in co-op modes, pvp, or special opperation, you get a high chance for rare Random loot pick ups just by clicking on what you clicked on you only get a few chances tho like 4 or 3 I think? Only at the end of the match win or lose I think? been too long since I played StarConflict. Good luck to anyone wanting to build a destroyer, good luck... That's one issue I have for building ships I wanted to build, takes a llllooooonnnnggggg time. Unless you pay for the bundles then you saved your time. And then the gameplay... The matches feel too much of the same to once you play them. Over and Over again. This game has the phone game app feeling in it, I mean jsu t play it for a good few hours and then you know that feelong too the maps get boring after a while. You play the same maps many times, Yeah I know the game random picks the maps for you so that you don't have to vote for which map you wanted to play. Makes it little better from the repeditive gameplay you'll experience in this game. You won't get easily killed as a level 1 in co-op, until like level 6 then yeah you'll get killed easily, If your not reckless. PvP is alright, you can go and test your skills that you learned from playing and go against other players that may have stronger weapons and a better ship then you. The controls aren't much of a problem its quite simple in my opinion don't know about you. Weapons can be upgraded on the ship you selected, and other upgrades can be put on the ship for better performance of that ship, The AI decent and they are easy, hard or annoying to kill in co-op, if your not reckless that is... yeah you might get ganged up by a huge group of them and die. But the AI is easy, hard or annoying to take on. If you want to play this game, play if you want to experience a repeditive gameplay. Nobody wants that type of game downloaded right? Last but not least, the Factions. You can choose one the 3 or 4..? factions you wanted to join in and work them. But honestly, there is little to no diffence to whatever side you. They alll feel the same to each other, except for the missions they give to do. So it doesn't matter what side you choose. there is nothing that special that you do in any of those factions you join. There is nothing else left for any of them.. I give this game a 5/10 just a straight up 5/10 from little fun to boring.

content:
r 25, 2013
												Edit: I'm rewritting this review, since there has been some changes after I wrote the original one.I've been playing this game for more than one year and I think I can give you a balanced review. First of all: This game is not Star Citizen, or Eve Online or Elite Dangerous. It doesn't want to be either. This game is a lobby based, free to play fighting arena game, settled in space. You have several ships at your disposal, with different classes and a lot of modules and modifiers to customize their performance. Then you go into battle in teams against other people in several game modes like the usual team battle, king of the hill, capture points etc... So far really standard. We can say that it is very similar to Warthunder of World of tanks, but with spaceships regarding the pvp skirmish matches. Then you have also High end content for clans with rewards if you conquer some of the sectors, which is nice for hardcore players, since you can even win a few premium currency here and there.NEW!: High end content has been reworked and now you can battle other corporations with your own corporate dreadnought. The attacks and defences are all happening in the open world map, so it is all integrated in the same place, instead of random sectors as it was before. So far it looks nice and helps with immersion. Dread battles feel like a mashup of all modes, since you have beacons (dread tactical devices) bombs, and a lot of tactical choices. The battle feels gorgeous and I remember in the first 2 or 3 games I was just watching the new graphics instead of playing.The only problem so far is that most of the corporations just fight over the small sectors, and the tier 4 were contested in the first week and since they they haven't changed. I suppose with time more and more people will join the fray. But the tier 3 sectors are really, really contested.And finally, what makes this game very balanced is that you can also play missions or scenarios in a Co-op fashion with friends, or straight open world and do PvP (pilot killing) or PvE vs AI. The open world is not like Eve online, is more like a huge sandbox map, with some RPG like missions (go there, kill 4 wolfs, come back, go there, pick some asteroids and return) and people to interact with. But you have respawns and you don't lose your stuff if you are killed, so it is more arcadish.Good thing is that the open world comes with a simple manufacturing tab which allows you to manufacture special ammo, weapons and consumables with the resources collected in there, and also 3 top tier ships which can be configured as you want when you are building them. The business model is akin to said games (warthunder, world of tanks) so you have to play and unlock ships with experience, credits and several special currency to get better and better modules. Investing money in the game gives you economical advance, as it is usual in this games, but so far there is nothing you can get with gold that you can't get for free. You will just have it later. Concerning most of the complains about the pay to win in premium ships, premium ships are not better than standard ships. They have the same slots than their credit counterparts, and the bonus are different, but not better. Modules can be shared between ships so there is no difference either. The problem is that in the tech tree, the credit ships appear with their level 1 stats, and premiums always appear with full level, because they are sold that way. But after you level your credit ships you will see that the premium ships are not better. So my final verdict is still a 9, because the Dreadnoughts are still in developing (not tier 5 Dreads yet) but we are almost there. All other balance issues with the new consumables had been fixed, and currently only the Destructor weapon is a pain in high tier beacon games. But I hope they will fix it as well.PROS: - Good art and graphics. - Runs well in mid and low end computers. - Free to play, it won't hurt your wallet if you try it. - Fast paced action and a good number of game modes. - PvP, PvE, and a sandbox with both, all in the same game. - SPACE DUDE!! SPACE!!! CONS: - A good chunk of the population is russian, so expect longer than average waiting times out of russian or european prime time. - Servers are a bit unstable sometimes, but this is something I'm finding in almost any late game. - Population is not as high as in mainstream games like world of tanks or warthunder. You won't notice it in low - mid tiers, but top end content lacks a bit of players.

content:
9, 2015
												It's a nice game overall. Perhaps the best space fight simulation game I've ever seen. I especially like the combination of sandbox flavor and "WoT" flavor: You can immediately jump into a PVP or PVE fight from the hanger, and you could also choose to loot resources by traveling through systems. Good news: your ship won't be lost if destroyed during a loot. Unlike EVE. That's good to know.   As most people have pointed out, like World of Tanks, this is a "pay to advance" game instead of a "pay to win" game. What you can really do is use dollars to: 1. buy premium ships and jump directly to the corresponding tier; 2. buy premium license to accelerate synapse and credit gain. Neither will help you win in the game. It might actually hinder winning, since jumping to high tiers means you lack the experience to fight those veterans.  Honestly, I might be one of the "wallet warriors" some people refer to. I'm willing to spend a considerable amount of dollars into a game that I really like. And Star Conflict is one of them.

number of helpful: 9 of 17 people (53%) found this review helpful
content:
27, 2015
												This game deserves more attention than it has gotten. The flight system is a modified version of the one used in Warthunder and expirienced players will have no trouble. It can take a few minutes to get used to flying with no down or up (because in space down is where ever the floor is and up is where ever your head is pointing, not because this is one of those crappy 2d space games), but it can by fun to disorient players by coming at them along an odd attack angle. The game forces players to think in 3d, going under and over to flank instead of around, because there is no down in space. The crafting system works well and forces you to carefuly consider your play style. Best of all the dreaded "Pay to Win" system is mor limited than most. Synergy (exp) transpher, DLC, and Premium ships are the only noticable advantages. Premium ships are usually much weaker than their Synergy required counterparts and are so over priced only the desprat and the rich bother to get them outside of a very generous sale every year or so. Over all the game is well ballanced (except for the occasional max level russian), and easy to play. There is controler support and Occulus use is avalable. The graphics are exelent if you can run at max level, and are better than many paid games.The only real drawbacks are the dwindling player base because the developers put all of the advertising budget into their flagship game Warthunder and allowd Star Conflict to fade into relative obscurity. It has a server infrastructure to match and it is not uncommon for the NA players to end up in Russian, Europian, and even South Asian servers with clear favoratim for Russian players as they are the majority of the population. However this advantage is waining as more and more internet lines are replaced with fiber optic cables.If youre a fan of arcade space flight and combat sims, this game is for you.

content:
0, 2016
												I play the game for many years (3?). It's very nice and fun - until you get to rank 6. Then you either go farm open space or you may continue with arenas which turn into horrible pop-fest where you are the one being popped non-stop - and I'm talking about experience of above-average player. Still the game is free and initially it's fun so you should definitely try it.Pros:nicely designed arena instances (both art and tactical layout);good looking ships;different play style for different classes of ships;quick initial progression;nicely designed combat;interesting open space sectors / treasure hunt / crafting concept;game run well on old PCs;a lot of different weapon types;decent horizontal equipment progression;decent AI.Cons:"PvE" and "vs AI" modes are badly balanced after rank 6 - as rank 6 you'll face L9 NPCs with epic-grade equipment;as often happen in PvP arena games - pre-mades roflstomp casual players, you tend to lose matches much more often than win them;heavily P2W mid/end-game: most powerful ships (destroyers, crafted L15) must be purchased or require months of focused farm (for example after *2+ years* I'm not even close to get any of those - it will take at least +1 more year);mid/end-game progression is too slow unless you purchase premium status, combined with NPCs and premades killing you non-stop it feels like a visit to a dentist without painkillers;badly designed mid-end-game may turn your progression into vertical wall;open space / treasure hunt / crafting are underdeveloped and could take a lot of polish and improvements;scarce resources for equipment progression, no point to waste them until you get to rank 14-15 ships.Conclusion:game is very fun in the beginning, has awful mid/end-game and has very interesting (but underdeveloped) open space, treasure hunting and crafting concepts. Despite flawed end-game I like it more than all other spaceship MMO games as a casual player.

number of helpful: 18 of 35 people (51%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
er 10, 2016
AbstractI have been playing Star Conflict for so long...like, before Open Space was actually useful. I decided that it was probably time to finally write a review...especially since there is a bunch of reviews on here with people that are either grinding out hours on there to make a review look worthy, or have literally played the game for so long and then write a crap review about it. Star Conflict I would have to say is mixed up hard. In my honest opinion on the game, it has ups and downs. Some of the reviews are legit on here, others make no sense to me. Lets see what makes up the integrity of Star Conflict and then rate it.GameplayStar Conflict in a nutshell is a pew-pew-pew competitive space shooter with both massively multiplayer elements that rush stuff and a slower more singleplayer side. I remember a time when the game was in it's early stages and the dreadnaughts had no even come out. I can't tell if the game has gotten better or worse since then. There are multiple modes in Star Conflict; PvP, PvE, Co-op v AI, and Open Space; on the higher tiers you have Tournament level stuff where high level players can team up against each other or against a huge enemy. PvP is what you expect, You vs. the other team. In PvP, there can be different objectives, my favorite personally being Combat Recon; one ship on each team is randomly chosen to be the commander for their respective teams. Your goal is to destroy the enemy commander and wipe out the rest of the team. After the commander is destroyed, no more respawns are allowed for that team. This diversity in gameplay allows for a lot of different playstyles, which brings me to my next topic.The vessels and factions in Star Conflict are incredible. From what I've gathered, Empire ships are high fire rate, (relatively) low damage and fast. However, they also have really powerful and really slow sniper ships equipped with a thermal cannon weapon known as a "Disentigrator". Federation ships are basically support type ships that use drones and stuff. Their fighters tend to be really good with escaping enemy grasps and showing up from behind and taking out enemies. Jericho ships are basically go big or go home. Shield tanky vessels that are slow and deliver a punch of built correctly. Their fighters love to just tank damage. Each faction has their own ships and each ship can be of a different class and type. This variety just lets the player play like they want to. I like the giant tanky sniper/full frontal force vessels of Jericho origin (more on that later).The only problem I have with SC in the gameplay category is how certain things are done. You can manufacture ships (more on that in a moment), but the resources required for some vessels can take months to collect if done correctly and without buy stuff. I will say that SC is really good about not pushing pay-to-play stuff in your face, there is a screen that pops up about it when you launch the game, and if you close it, bam that's all you see. Open space was also a joke until Dreadnaughts came along that required Iridium to manufacture. There was no point to OS until then. Gaijin has gotten really good about it now and added a lot of features.Also since it's a match based (apart from Open Space) you have to enter a queue (like in war thunder) to get into a match, occasionally, it can be really bad, but on average it's fine and easily overlooked timewise.Downfalls and DestroyersMatchmaking can be a jerk sometimes. I'm a rank 9 or 10 (kind of in the middle) mercenary, and I'm continuously paried with rank 15 players if I throw my rank 10 ship into my ship pool. I hate the way that's done but anywhere before rank 10, matchmaking is fine. That's the biggest downfall I think.Another would be the resourcing you do to manufacture ships. I didn't make this pain in the neck process number one, because it's totally optional. :)Luckily, the best loot used for ships like Destroyers and Dreadnaughts are obtained through the loot drops at the end of battles. Like I said earlier, resourcing and matchmaking can be bad, but since they finally made OS useful with Destroyers and Dreadnaughts, it's not so bad. The turn out on this one however is that most people don't like the new Destroyers update. I don't know why, I think it's becuase they think it's unbalanced; but here's the thing. if you start out as a new player or stopped playing for a while, all the rank ups you get in a faction literally just hand you the components needed for the destroyer. BOOM. Easy as pie. And all the while you're accrewing the materials, you are earning money, making up for the 3 million credits you need to manufacture one. Dreadnaughts on the other hand require some more explanation.Dreadnaughts are about 10 fold or more, powerful than a destroyer. These massive battlecruisers are constructed by corporations (mainly corporations that house a group of 10 players, rank 10 or more). Corporations are like factions in the game. These dreadnaughts however take a lot of time to make, but once you do, your corporation can engage in sector combat...another gameplay mode. You can take control of sectors in open space. I think that's insanely cool, but thats just me.RatingsGraphics: 8/10 (Really nice, some textures can be made better, but the attention to detail on the guns (how they move with the cursor and whatnot, is really well done)Gameplay and mechanics:  6/10 (Can be improved apon still. Grinding out resources isn't my favorite thing to do, but the payout is about 80% worth it after you rank the ship up some.)Lore/History: 9/10 (Well done, each faction has leaders and each leader has their own biography. The stations themselves have lore and pretty much every sector has lore behind it as well. Very well done.)Downfalls/Repetitiveness: 5/10 (Very grindy, leveling up can be a pain in the neck after like rank 4 or 5, fixed by maxing out the synergy on your owned ships to increasy your fleet strength synergy gain percentage)Overall Rating: 7.5/10 (Best competivive F2P game I've ever played)

space ship!Obviously this game isn't for everyone it has a small target audience, but if you are like me and love your sci-fi and really want to fly then you might like this game.It's a space flight sim at its core but it isn't super complex with every button on the keyboard doing something like the old X-wing and Tiefighter games.The game sports heaps of different types of ships and classes ranging from heavy engineering frigates to fast interceptors meaning that there is a ship in the game will probably be to your liking.As you progress through the levels you start getting access to more weapons and moduals and each level and tier you go up sees you looking through your new ships equipment slots seeing what new toys you can put on your ship. And this really does make it feel like the ship is your own.overall if you enjoy your sci fi and your fying games like Hawx I would suggest you give this game a go and if you like it well then enjoy.

content:
ry 28, 2014
												To quicky describe this game, I use, "It's like World of Tanks, but with starfighters instead of tanks." Now, for a longer description, this game is actually pretty damn good. It's got solid gameplay, nice visuals, and I really like it. There are three classes of ships, and three sub classes for each. The three classes are 1: interceptors, which are fast moving lightly armored ships, 2: fighters, which are medium armed and armored and overall versatile ships, and 3: frigates, which are big, heavy, and slow moving ships. I won't go in depth with the sub classes, but for interceptor they are recon, covert ops, and ECM; fighters get gunship, command, and tackler; and frigates get long range, engineering, and guard. Each sub class has there own special main ability, or 'module' and a selection of other modules which are unique to that sub class, and there is also a selection of other multi-purpose modules that are avialible to all ships, no matter the class or sub class. Now, I think I've gone on ranting enough for this game, and if you've read this far, you've probably got the general idea of the game. I hope to see you up in the battle feild!

content:
1, 2015
												This game is truly amazing. It has surprising graphics and features for a "free to play" game and is also very easy to run on just about any computer (within reason). SC is a very fast paced game with a somewhat slow learning curve. If you are willing to take your time and learn to appreciate the little things in this game it will only get better for you from there. The difference in ship complexity from the lowest level (T1) to the highest level (T5) is absolutely astounding. Like I said before; this game has a somewhat slow learning curve, so ask around in the community. For the most part people are much friendlier in this game than any other online games I've played and many of the pilots are very glad to help out newbs or just about anyone. A lot of the reviews on here do more complaining than good, so I'd like to remedy that. I have logged over 1000 hours in this game and have never run into any problems with the devs, mods or supervisors of any kind. So, any reviews you may have seen saying "Oh, this game sucks because the mods are irresponsible and rude." are just not true. As a matter of fact, I know many of the mods personally and they are all great guys that love the role that they play in the game. I hope this review helped you join the game. Star Conflict is a constantly changing and updating world with many possibilities that will come along if more people are added. Overall I reccomend this game highly to anyone that is willing to spend time in a great community with endless possibilities in the future, not to mention amazing gameplay :)

												I strongly recommend this game. While it is indeed, as they say, *grindy*, it is very fun to play.My hope is that they will decrease the grind later on overall, but if you focus on maxing outthe synergy of T1/2 you'll have a faster time synergizing the ship types you like to use in T3+. I suggest finding a good class after you finish T2, and grind it straight to T5. You'll be able to get the ships you want faster by using this method. Once in T5, you can even gain huge amounts of extra synergy.Of course, currently, if you want to transfer extra synergy to other ships that you just don't want to grind, you can simply pay a small fee to transfer the synergy from your T5 ship to your T3+ ships when you wish to skip a few ships to the one you like.Again, I really enjoy this game and will start playing it again as soon as I gain a computer that won't fry on me like the last one. :D                                 That is all                                                                           - WolfKhan

content:
er 3, 2014
												Updated Review:So this has been my favorite game on Steam for a long time, and I have the hours to show for it. I like the  great graphics, multiple styles of space combat, and interesting missions. The types of ships always provide a new challenge, and they are generally fun to play.  You can go into open space, and fly around doing missions, or compete in PVE or PVP missions.    There are tiny Interceptors, Giant Destroyers, massive Corp ships (you dont get to pilot),  and new alien ships.  The game is constantly updated, and gets plenty of money so it is likely to stay for a while.  I would recommend this game for many reasons, most importantly because it is fun to play.  So that's the good part, and why I still say it's worth playing. My biggest issue with the game is that when a new piece of content is released, they encourage paying for the parts instead of building it the slow way. They make it really hard  to earn the parts for new ships. I personally invested so many hours into this game because I enjoyed making the secret project ships, (a top tier ship you can craft with parts you collect through gameplay).  The new alien ships, and even destroyers were easy to craft immediately if you spent the money. I find this both frustrating, and pointless. The premium ships and licenses are already available to reward game donors (of which I am one).   The new ships should require effort and playing hours to unlock, instead of repeatedly making plays for quick money.  I love this game, and will keep playing, but I refuse to pay to fast track any ships.  For those who read this review, I would say it can be a lot of fun to play this game, but don't bother paying real money to build your stuff. Just do it the slow way, and i fyou want to spend money, buy the DLC packages, and wait until a 50%  sale before purchasing.  You get GS, licenses, premium ships, and permantent bonuses. It's really the only value you get by paying into the game, besides supporting a game you play.

												I've been playing Star Conflict now for about a week and I have to say, its very fun.  The PVE missions I've done are quick, about 10 - 15 minutes, and the PVP is excellent as well. I have really only two points that I feel are issues, the first is that there is a real lack of information about game play especially the open world. Secondly the game model is built on tier farming your way through the game. This is ok as the combat is fun, but it could really be made less tedious if there were more open space missions or exporation going on. In short, I recommend this game for anyone that would like to play a fast paced, space shooter an hour or so a day.

												This game certainly isn't the best Space-sim.Although the graphics are fairly good, the game does not give you any information as to what you are supossed to do after that: It gives no tips or guides in knowing what currencies do what, what upgrades are preffered, etc. Quests are also in a disarray. The game also seems to be leaning towards money tranactions.The matchmaking takes several minutes; and the gameplay, within itself, is not very good. PvP is all too easy/impossible, the only thing that matters is who is on the tale of the other: If you are being pursued, you are a dead pilot flying. If you are chasing... the person who you are chasing is gonna get it. That is really all there is too it, sadly. This game is free, and thank goodness for that. I got it to test out an old-gen Oculus Rift, and I can't say I've gotten around to it.

content:
y 8, 2015
												I downloaded this game a few weeks ago, and finally got around to playing it a couple of days ago. I've only spent a few hours on it so far, but from what I can see it's based quite heavily on in-game purchases and DLC... I'm anything but good at these sort of games however, and I very much doubt that I'll be able to progress to a point where moving forwards is only possible through buying licenses and currency.In the early stages of the game- it's fun and enjoyable. I haven't gotten into it seriously at all, but it's still good for just messing about and having battles. If you're interested in the space battle genre but aren't planning to make this game a lifestyle, I strongly recommend it solely for the fact that it's free, and the early levels don't require any additional purchases. I'm not planning to dedicate myself to this game fully, and as a result I can enjoy fighting in a few battles in the evenings and exploring. If you're hoping to become more absorbed into Star Conflict and dedicate more time to it- then I do warn you that you will need to be willing to spend a fair bit of money to progress.

content:
, 2015
												This game is a ton of fun. It may not be for everyone, but I like it.I will admit that this game is a bit tough to get through the bot filled tier 1 phase, and then the early under equipped phases when you finally make it to a new tier. However, with some planning on what to buy and when, this can be mitigated somewhat. I think it does a really good job of converting some of the familiar traditional flight combat sim mechanics into a more twitch based space theme. It forgoes a good bit of realism, but allows for more interesting matchmaking game modes, and an arcadey shooter feel.I definitely suggest checking it out, especially since it requires no real investment to get started and look around.

												Its fun for a few minutes, then it gets frustratingly hard to progress, and even when you do, its not rewarding.It takes forever to get paired up in a matchIf you play PvP, you die a lot and don't get xpIf you play PvE, some opped-out Russian steals all your kills and you don't get xpIf you play exploration/out-of-match questing, you don't get xp, money or any satisfaction whatsoeverThe only way to get xp/money is to buy membership to double the miniscule ammount of xp/money you do get.Don't spend money to buy ships; they're no better than any others. 												Unless you want an exercise in frustration with Pay2Win tactics, patching that changes the entire premise of the game and generally frustrating gameplay and teammates, stay away from this absolute pile of ♥♥♥♥. NOT A FREE GAME.To make matters worse, getting items (a.k.a. loot) is now a pay-to-win system too. Here's how you get items: Win, firstly. Then you have 3 'chances' to uncover items, usually finding 'debris' which is just vendor trash that sells for 10% of market value. THEN you have to 'recover' any items you actually found, which is a 10% chance to do so. 30% if you want to pay real money. So you have a 50% chance, then a 30% chance and a 10% chance on top of that. Do the math friends, stay away from this Russian piece of crap.

content:
3, 2013
												I used to like playing this game, because it was an action arcade 3rd person space shooter. Ticking all the right boxes of my predilections. However, after a few updates, the game became grindy very quickly. You now have to use ships incessantly to get “synergy” which upgrades them, unless you buy a premium ship. Repairs cost money unless you buy premium. I stopped playing for a few months and then went back with the new update. Wow was I surprised, they have now made the game 1000% more grind orientated. You used to upgrade ships based on usage, it was free. Now you need to grind for it, not just for synergy but faction synergy, or you can use universal synergy with cost money. You also have to grind to upgrade ship components, oh and with multiple requirements, or you can pay.Instead of working on ship balancing or gameplay fun or even matchmaking queues (as the wait times for a match are ridiculous), all attention is focused on money and how to squeeze more from you. Oh and forget about the free roam stuff, that has a limit installed, you can only do a few missions per day, and then you have to wait for it to reset. Yep, loads of fun right?!Honestly I'm surprised they haven't monetised the log in.Stay away from this rubbish.

												A great game with a decent concept that's plagued by a horrible progression system that encourages you to trend towards microtransactions. Add in to the fact you have to spend real-world money just to part up with anymore than two people, and you have a recipe for your standard greedy microtransaction based game.the gameplay itself is fairly solid, ship-to-ship combat is interesting and the game looks and plays great. Its just a shame that its burdened by such terrible design decisions. I would've gladly paid 50+ dollars for a game like this, but the constant need to spend reworld money (or spend an absurd amount of time grinding) keeps me from spending any sort of cash on games like this.

content:
ry 19, 2014
												I'll break my review into two parts; the pro and cons.Pro:1) Addictive game. Very fun to play and never gets boring2) Great customization. Shields, speed, attack damage, attack speed, critical damage, etc. Almost everything on your ship is customizable. If you lose, it's your own fault. Not the game's.Cons1) Community and GMs. You can chat about anything you want on SC...if the right GM is online. You will be banned from chatting (for 1 hour) if you write things the GMs disagree about. For example, A) On the US server you can only type in English. Typing in Spanish or any other language will get you banned for an hour. B) Be very careful of your political comments. I have seen people get banned for mentioning "Obama" or "Obamacare". You are free to say anything about Romney though. C) If you want to kick back and chat instead of dog fighting all day, you can get banned for chatting too much. D) if you chat about how much the exchanges in the game cost (cash for standards) you will get banned.E) Complaining about the launch time for pve or pvp will get you banned.Btw, the term "Ban" in the above comments mean you won't be able to type in the chat for one hour. You can still play but you can't talk.Summary, great game but horrible GMs.

content:
er 28, 2014
												The core part of this game is fun and I'll continue to pick and poke at it despite not recommending it, to anyone, ever.For whatever reason, it is not possible to play on a server that offers a lag free gaming environment.  The dev's have decided that they want shorter queing times, even if this means that the matches you are given are routinely unplayable due to terrible server destinations.  I've checked this out on the game's forums, and many people complain about it.  The devs claim everything is "working as intended".The really annoying thing about this is that players are heavily penalized by server side lag.  If you tough it out and stay in a laggy match, your personal stats suffer, and your progression is slowed.   If you leave a laggy match, you're locked out of looking for a new one until the old match expires.  Though it hasn't happened to me, I've heard a lot of talk about people facing temperary bans for leaving matches that are simply unplayable.This issue could be cleared up with a larger player base, maybe...  I can't imagine the path Star Conflict would take to get those players.  Since the game is free to play, new players have no vested interesting in completely what could be a 1000+ hours of grind on servers that seem to be positioned somewhere between where you want to play from, and the moon.War Thunder, also from Giajin, is an all around better game for those looking for something fun and free to play.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
18, 2014
												Update 6/20/16Lol holy ♥♥♥♥ this game is a ♥♥♥♥ing joke. The grinding is actuallythe worst setup I've ever seen in a game. Either spend hours, literally consecutively for months all day every day, playing the game to make slow progress, or make none at all and try to play it casually. Teamwork is non existant, if you're a frigate in PvP glhf. Even if you use a good PvP ship for your level with maxed equipment, the ranking system is absolutely horrible. I queued with all rank 7 ships and was thrown in a game where the vast majority had rank 10+ ships, and I know it's not based on survivability because theirs was obviously signifigantly higher than mine was. Open world is still unbalanced as all Hell, lower level players can't leave the station without getting destroyed. Leveling up makes absolutely no sense. I take that back, I'm sure you can figure it out after hours of messing around in the game, but they really never explain the leveling system at all other than what synergy is and how to buy new ships. I logged on to get my reward and had no new guns or equipment from the last time had logged on, then logged off. I logged on 30 minutes later only to have randomly unlocked a slew of new equipment and alien weapons that was apparently supposed to be automatically given to me once I got a rank 7 ship, which I have several of. The new support ships are really cool, the only downside is that the grind for them takes so damn long. They came out late last year and I just talked to a casual player, someone who doesn't waste their time playing this game nonstop, and he told me he started manufacturing his support ship the day he could and he was just recently able to finish it last week. They're cool and all but for the grind it couldn't be any less worth it. The transfer rate for GS to credits is still a huge slap in the face, there's honeslty no need to explain just check for yourself or take my word. It seems like the devs did a great job improving the handling of the ships and hit registration, however with every update they seem to find a way to make the grind even harder if you don't supply them with a constant flow of cash.I'd also like to add that they still haven't made the game any more enjoyable for new players. I stopped playing this game for months and when I came back I was able to get back into it pretty easily. My friend however had only played enough to get a rank 2 ship and getting into the game was just impossible. I queued with him usuing a rank 2 ship and we were against players that were in rank 4-5 ships PvP and with rank 4-5 ships in PvE which made the difficulty harder. Tiers 1 and 2 are still as awful as they always have been since they made it pay to win and it doesn't look like they're planning on changing that, making it offputting to new players. Tier 3 is better but there is a noticable difference between rank 7 and rank 8 ships that can make some battles very unbalanced. A new weapon added during my hiatus, the Flux Phaser, makes playing certain fighters a whole lot easier. I for example love using it on my Commander ships because it allows me to keep good distance and deal signifgant damage. A lot of people seem to think the weapon is overpowered, mainly because they've been hit by more than one ship using a Phaser at once, but this brings up the teamwork aspect of this game. There is a video on YouTube of a coordinated team all using Phasers and they were melting ships in seconds, but that would happen with pretty much every weapon because they were focusing their fire on one or two ships at a time. The weapon itself is pretty balanced, the only real edge it has is that it's extremely easy to master using because of it fires homing shots. If you think that's OP then you have to think the beam cannon is OP because its a ♥♥♥♥ing 100% accurate laser that travels at the speed of light that progressively gets stronger over time. My only complaint about the Flux Phaser is that I don't like how wierd it can be to shoot. Sometimes when I'm in a fight and spamming it I'll run into issues like the shot popping too early or the shot being fired when I let go of LBM then instantly popping. Other than that it's fun. I have't gotten to really look at the Mass Driver yet, the new weapon for frigates (at least I think it is, I never saw when I used to play), but I can't say it's something I think will be usefull on all frigates. For example I'm not sure I'd put it on my Guard ship because of the low rate of fire and weaker damage. Its better on LRF's which can shoot faster and need a good close range weapon other than the Beam Cannon to deal with Interceptors and Fighters that get too close.Pros:Great flight mechanicsGreat fighting mechanicsGreat graphics, especially for a F2PA cool ranking system with the potential to be funNice communityA good amount of eventsFun missionsCons:Hardcore pay to winUnbalanced matchmakingExtremely tedious grindNew ships are always high rank shipsVeteran friendly, very hard for new players to get into and enjoyEvents usually require a specific weapon or skill level that only higher level players would haveThe occasional ♥♥♥♥ ♥♥♥♥♥All that aside I'll still play it casually, I just can't recommend anyone get into the game unless they're willing to dish out some dough and put a ♥♥♥♥ ton of hours into the game.------------------------------------------{Old review}I can no longer suggest this game to new players after the last few updates.You can no longer pick your teammates up in PvE mode unless you have a one time use duplicator, which is a waste of time and money to get just to revive one person. (A lot of people at higher ranks have hundreds, but it's still an uneccessary addition to the game that only serves the purpose of adding a little extra difficulty to the grind.)Missile launchers in PvE respawn almost instantly making it ridiculously hard. (fixed to a degree)The open world idea is good, but it has no balance. If you go in with an Interceptor, you have the speed to get out of fights, but not enough defense/power to survive. If you use a Fighter, you have decent power and defense, but you're still too slow to escape the sometimes brutal skirmishes with NPC's. If you go in with a Frigate, you have the power and defense to fight, but you're far too slow you run away if you have to. (♥♥♥♥ you)This may just be me, but since the last time I got on, I've noticed a sharp decrease in the amount of synergy and credits I get after a fight. I got a premium license to see if I could get more syn/creds and it just ended up giving me the normal amount from before. (♥♥♥♥. you.)I want to like this game, I really do, but the developers have finally set it up where it is completely pay to win. To survive PvE, you need a premium ship and duplicators. To survive skirmishes, you need a premium ship with a ton of active module spots. To survive open world, you once again need a premium ship with extra module spots. If you want any synergy or creds, you need to buy a premium license. This game was really fun when it first came out, now it's no different than the other F2P games on Steam. Get out your credit card or go home.

y 14, 2015
												Its fun for a few minutes, then it gets frustratingly hard to progress, and even when you do, its not rewarding.It takes forever to get paired up in a matchIf you play PvP, you die a lot and don't get xpIf you play PvE, some opped-out Russian steals all your kills and you don't get xpIf you play exploration/out-of-match questing, you don't get xp, money or any satisfaction whatsoeverThe only way to get xp/money is to buy membership to double the miniscule ammount of xp/money you do get.Don't spend money to buy ships; they're no better than any others. Gold-class ships only have to perk of generating extra synergy which (yes you guessed it) you have to pay more money to transfer to your other ships because they start off maxxed (which also does nothing).No matter how much time and energy you put into upgrading your ships, there will always be at least 10 other people in your match who paid real money to get overpowered weapons, ships, and modules to be a million times better than you.Community sucks.Customer support sucks unless you're Russian.Guard ships and Long-Range ships are rediculously OP, especially in PvPThe only way you progress is being really good or paying money; there's no graduation of difficulty, or benefits for new players; its hard right away, and stays hard.Perks:-the combat is cool when you're not dying constantly-3D movement is cool as well, but would be cooler if the scenery didn't force you to think in a 2D manner.-stars-yelling at your teammates for wiping the group1/10 you could easily skip this one

number of helpful: 5 of 10 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
ry 3, 2014
												The game when starting was AWESOME, basically the same stuff than War Thunder but with space-ships.The controls are kinda hard when beggining but when you get used to them they are really funny and entretaining.A lot of ships, meaning a lot of game time to get used to each one of them and learning their strong points and flaws, also very entretaining.A some-what great community (at least on global chat).Thats the pretty part of the game... only when you start.After unlocking the third or fourth ship... everything went into the grindfest:1.PvE restricts you to 1 or 2 missions with different difficulty (easier and you dont earn nothing OR impossible and still dont earn a lot), thats why you can do party with low leveled people and take your Tier 5 ship into the first mission on easy.2.PvP is extremely unbalanced, since you can get more than half of new players with Tier 1 ships against a team with Tier 5-6 ships.3.The grind after a while becomes ridiculous, you go from a kinda affordable ship to one that takes WEEKS or even MONTHS to unlock, of course... you have to LV UP the ship that was BEFORE the one that you want to unlock if you want to do so.4.Upgrades follow the same path, since this game was made for people buying memberships that gives boosts (and lets not mention the premium ships which gives an even more insane boost) so you basically have to spend real money constantly to keep the ingame currency on a stable flow, since not only upgrades becomes insanely expensive but the price of the REPAIRS that you must carry to make your ships "usable" again takes at least 60% (If not more) of the battle rewards.5.Lag, yeah, lag, even if this game its not that demanding, there are many situations (and with many means ALL the time) which the screen gets so heavily loaded with effects, explosions and stuff, that either, you end up blind until everything goes away OR you get hard lagged and crash against a random rock floating in the scene.6.Either or you get a incredible win streak (which means the PvP matchmaking working properly, which it never happens.) PLUS membership PLUS premium ships to keep a somewhat "stable" currency flow, or you have to go back to previous Tiers, meaning more and more grinding.7.Faction system is worthless, since you can pay a sum of game currency and simply switch to another faction, same goes for clan wars, there is not a "real" reason of being in one.This game is fun up to a point, after that, it just gets annoying, unless you have fun with hours and hours of grinding, rogue-like teammates that basically are kill-hoggers, which means that if the whole team gets crushed they wont care, they got their kill, DLCS and "I got the most OP premium ship in the game" players, then this is your game.(By the way: this goes for War Thunder too, but with planes.)

content:
3, 2013
												I used to like playing this game, because it was an action arcade 3rd person space shooter. Ticking all the right boxes of my predilections. However, after a few updates, the game became grindy very quickly. You now have to use ships incessantly to get “synergy” which upgrades them, unless you buy a premium ship. Repairs cost money unless you buy premium. I stopped playing for a few months and then went back with the new update. Wow was I surprised, they have now made the game 1000% more grind orientated. You used to upgrade ships based on usage, it was free. Now you need to grind for it, not just for synergy but faction synergy, or you can use universal synergy with cost money. You also have to grind to upgrade ship components, oh and with multiple requirements, or you can pay.Instead of working on ship balancing or gameplay fun or even matchmaking queues (as the wait times for a match are ridiculous), all attention is focused on money and how to squeeze more from you. Oh and forget about the free roam stuff, that has a limit installed, you can only do a few missions per day, and then you have to wait for it to reset. Yep, loads of fun right?!Honestly I'm surprised they haven't monetised the log in.Stay away from this rubbish.

												NIce idea, bad approach.Game play has a steep learning curve, if you can get past the curve it can be fun.  The tiers for PVE are too large, after tier 4 there is 5 ranks of ships to top of tier and all PVE encouters are based on rank 9. Open world is extremely difficult under rank 6-7 and the difficulty scales up rapidly.Modules require multiple faction credit and it costs to change factions.Leveling without cash shop is near impossible past rank 6, and the caash shop prices are too expensive.  No micro purchases, everything is in the 5-50 dollar range.Terrible group ques for PVP. Want to play with a group of friends, more than one will see regular 5+ minute wait times.

content:
9, 2014
												1.250 hours on the clock. What more is to say?++++++++++++++++++++++++++ Update on April 2nd; 2015:Maybe it is time to add something in response to some other so called reviews around here:There seem to be some players, who are talking about abusive admins etc. Since more than 1250 hours active game time I have seen not a single use of admin powers in terms of banning, let alone abuse.If you carefully read through those comments, they later all have to admit, that they were swearing, talking about drugs, using political names etc. For that, they got warnings and chat-mutes of a few hours.And now, we have some bad mooded kiddies who seek their revenge in negative comments.I suggest: if you ARE interested in this kind of game, try it for free. If you later decide to spend money on a DLC or Premium, you can do so by a personal opinion. Until then, you can enjoy the game for free.++++++++++++++++++++++++++Well, apperantly a lot. First - like a lot of those games (War Thunder etc.) you need to invest some hours to learn the game mechanics and what ship is doing what. Second, you need some patience, as this game is more or less in constant development. Sometimes they make it better, sometimes they make it worse. But, after all, it is free, and it generates a lot of fun. Especially, if you do it with a buddy or join one of the (better) corps (like clans) to play this together. There is PvP, PvE and an Open World Mode called Invasion (involves some Aliens).There are Premium ships, but they have not more killing potential than other, normal ships - they just don't need repairs and generates some % more free synergy (to level your other ships).Hint: don't spend your real money for transferring this synergy, but if you want, invest it in a licence to get more loot. If you have any questions, feel free to ask or go to the official forum pages @ forum.star-conflict.com

												It isn't open world. Just individual small maps. There is nothing but combat, no exploration or trading etc. You just spawn again when you die and you play in short "Red Vs Blue" matches where you could end up on either team. Not a lot to this game to be honest i was expecting more. Also the flight controls are very arcadey even when set to "EXPERT".  If you are looking for a Space combat game with simulation type controls this is not for you. Also there are nearly a dozen types of currency which is about ten too many.If you are looking for Call of Duty style deathmacthes in Space then this is it. It's very similar to Mech Warrior Online in many aspects (except for the respawning), but in a space game i dont like being boxed into a tiny map. Personally not what i want in a space game.

												It isn't open world. Just individual small maps. There is nothing but combat, no exploration or trading etc. You just spawn again when you die and you play in short "Red Vs Blue" matches where you could end up on either team. Not a lot to this game to be honest i was expecting more. Also the flight controls are very arcadey even when set to "EXPERT".  If you are looking for a Space combat game with simulation type controls this is not for you. Also there are nearly a dozen types of currency which is about ten too many.If you are looking for Call of Duty style deathmacthes in Space then this is it. It's very similar to Mech Warrior Online in many aspects (except for the respawning), but in a space game i dont like being boxed into a tiny map. Personally not what i want in a space game.

content:
6, 2016
Apparently going through a bad periode for nowPlease read full review, I often vote "meh" or neutral, since it doesn't exist I vote either up or down but its quite meaninglessIl be be more specefic of the cons, because the downside is what matter the most after your interested in the game--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Returning player, used to play before in 2014-ish, returned due to destroyer update (as I liked frigate gameplay, sadly now impossible to play)Is the game still enjoyable ? YesAs enjoyable as before ? NoBasically this game is a arena based gamePVP sets you in a arena with different objectives ranging for plantings bombs to team death matchs and capture points, you get unlimited respawn but in recon where the designed commander has to be alive to allow respawnPVE sets you in a different arena, sometime with 3 different section (allowing you to respawn after each section) or a 1 block mission like fire support (no respawn), objectifs are usually destroy designed targets/capture points/kill bossOpen space is explained in the rest of the reviewPros-Looks good-Ship handling is decent-3 faction to choose from with the only big game changer being the Long Range Frigate (LRF) for the Empire and Jericho as the ship capability are quite the same otherise for the same ship classes-Open space mod (more like linked arena maps, because its litteraly the PVP maps with bots & loot linked via portals most of the time)-Ship design is very caracteristic of a faction-Can run on potato PC-The game lore evolves with updates (some old map station in open space are now turned into wreck field)-Other stuff I didn't mentioned because I'm too lazy to remember themCons-New tiering / unlock system (January 2016) : For War Thunder players, its the same here minus the BR thingFor non War Thunder players : you have 5 tiers, to go the next tier you need to unlock every ship of the previous tier, so if your like 1 gameplay style your forced to play all the other one too if you want to unlock the next ship of your favourite class^This is one of the things that legit scares me, that system can as well act a scarecrow for new players driving them away and some already playing with itLRF rant mode on-Remember what I said about the LRF?Forget Jericho for 90% of the timeReview of Jericho LRF-Fire a manually guided torpedo travelling at ~500m per sec-AOE effect-Possible to detonate it at any moment-Create a radiation cloud dealing medium amount of damage for 6 second-Don't require a direct line of sight-Reload every 15 sec-Easy to dodgeCountersGuardian frigtate : module destroying any type of guided missileFlares : all ships can carry it and it reload rather fast, disable torpedo steering controlsSmall ships : outrun your torpedo speedReview of Empire LRF-Enter a sniper mod when activated, fire a projectile travelling at ~3km per sec-Weapon can't be fired directly after activation-Reload in 2.5 sec-Has +2km more range than a Jericho torpedo-Afterburn damage dealing 25% of you shot damage 0.5 sec later-Require a direct line of sight-Deal more damage than a Jericho torpedo-Hard to dodgeCounters-Solid cover-Small ships : hard to aim-Engineer shield wall wich nearly no one ever useDue to the huge firerate / projectile speed and countermeasure gap, torpedoes falls flat into the utteraly useless sectionLRF rant mode off-With the destroyer update frigate gameplay pretty much died outGuardian basically play the same role as their name, they guard allies with powerfull defensives modules, and act as meat shield so they got one of the best HP & shield stats, its good defence is countered by bad offensive capacity (mind that a figher is outgunning you)Destroyers get 3x their HP & shields stats, they are more bullet spongy (is that even a word?) than the ship with this specefic role in mind with the icing on top being actually able to kick asses and move fasterThe only viable firgate are engineers because you will always need a healer and the Empire LRF because of reasons stated earlier-Open space is generic, nothing special happen, bots go in, fight each other, rince & repeat, no event ever happen (not even sure if the alien invasion event still occure since open space was launched)There is really no point playing this mod aside from destroyer part grinding (wich will take weeks to months at least or half the component) and some blueprint for some modules / guns--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Speaking of destroyers, after reading negatives reviews (yes I read the negative one before the positive ones)  Il give you a tipOnce you can make one (assuming you didn't died of old age grinding the parts for it), take a screenshot where it says you have the ressources to do so, because from what I read of some negative reviews is that the support might give the "no proof no refund" excuse, if your game crash / get logged off when building one and it waste your ressouces for nothing in return, you have a proof to back you up

content:
er 2, 2016
												Star Conflict is a third person space combat game. The game currently features some PvP, PvE and PvAI scenarios. You get to pick one of three factions, Jericho, Federation and Empire, each with unique stats on their ships. The combat in Star Conflict feels solid, there's always bullets, plasma, lasers and rockets flying in all directions, and it's ships do not fly like Star Wars, as they fly like planes in space, here ships can remain still, move in all directions without limitations. You get to pick one of three ship types at first, Interceptor, Fighter and Frigate, from smallest to biggest.The game itself puts heavy focus on team work. PvE Missions and PvP requires some co-ordination with your team. Truth be told, when a team works together they are unstoppable. My favorite type of ships are the Fighters, and it's role Tacklers, focusing mostly on throwing de-buffs and cloacking behind enemy lines. This game is to be experienced with friends and comrades, and if you need someone to guide you, let me know, In-game my nick is Richyda. PS: If you wish, use this code to be my refferal, you instantly get me into your friend list, so would be easier to contact one another.D42BF26E5AFF755DBE6571472126F2A7 Use it just when you are about to select your starting faction, thanks!
